title: Attorney fees awarded against me, can they really wage garnish me?
question: Already paying 30% of my net paycheck, via income withholding order, for child support. (X gets check in the mail every week from my employer) Now I have to pay the X's attorney fees, 45k+. I read that child support wage garnishments can be up to 50% but others can only be 25%. So given 30% is already being taken from my weekly paycheck for child support and because attorney fees are not child support, student loans, or taxes and child support takes priority am i correct (read some American Payroll Association Congress 2012 workshop notes) that no more can be taken ? If so what can the creditor take from me? Can the family court do anything?
question_tags: Child support,Bankruptcy,Debt,Wage garnishment,Nondischargeable debt and student loans,Bankruptcy and debt,Family law,Working with a lawyer,Fees
answers: The Family Court made an order, it is a judgment and the attorney can collect on the judgment. Collection may include a number of things from wage garnishment, levy on bank accounts, sale of property etc. You should consult an attorney about your situation.

Yes they really can. I have seen over 100% garnished. You can even repay child support in a Chapter 13 to get some relief and have a budget you can live on but if you just let them garnish they can take everything. .
you need to discuss this issue with a family law attorney to get their opinion immediately.

The family court made the order. It is a judgment. The creditor can take cash in the bank, automobiles, art, a boat-- anything of value. Unlike support, a judgment for attorney's fees can be discharged in bankruptcy.
